docs.title: Welcome to CCSP Docs for IR-NIYANTRAC
docs.text:
The site provides useful documentation for CCSP deployment use cases such as IRNIYANTRAC and WGPS.

For more details visit Centre of Innovation for IoT/M2M.

docs.title: Welcome to IRNIYANTRAC Guide
docs.text: This section provides useful details about IRNIYANTRAC project and its messages.

docs.title: About IRNIYANTRAC
docs.text:
IRNIYANTRAC stands for "Indian Railways Native IoT based Yield Analysis Telemetry, Recording and Control". 
IR-NIYANTRAC is an application platform deployed by CRIS for monitoring and control of electrical assets and energy. 
The project not just helps in automation of electrical assets of railways but also in predictive and preventive maintainance of railways electrical assets.

For more details, please visit the IR-NIYANTRAC website.

docs.title: About IRNIYANTRAC
docs.text:
IRNIYANTRAC stands for "Indian Railways Native IoT based Yield Analysis Telemetry, Recording and Control". IR-NIYANTRAC is an application platform deployed by CRIS for monitoring and control of electrical assets and energy.

The project not just helps in automation of electrical assets of railways but also in predictive and preventive maintainance of railways electrical assets. Following 5 use cases are covered under it:

docs.title: About CCSP (C-DoT's Common Service Platform)
docs.text: C-DOT has developed a state-of-the-art, oneM2M-compliant C-DOT's Common Service Platform (CCSP), which facilitates standards-based IoT solutions deployment across the country.

docs.title: What is CCSP?
docs.text: CCSP is an indigenously developed IoT platform based on the oneM2M standard, which has been declared the National Standard on IoT/M2M by TEC. It acts as a horizontal common service layer for IoT/M2M, offering a set of Common Service Functions (CSFs) required by various IoT verticals.

docs.title: Supported IoT Verticals:
docs.text:
• Energy
  • Transport
  • Agriculture
  • Surveillance
  • Smart buildings
  • Smart street lights

docs.title: Features of CCSP
docs.text:
1. Common Service Functions (CSFs):
  2. Security
  3. Discovery
  4. Registration

  5. Device management

  6. Uniform APIs:

  7. These standardized APIs abstract complex aspects, such as:
    • Underlying device management technologies
    • Network technologies
    • Connectivity choices
    • Secure communication
    • Data formats

docs.title: Benefits for IoT Application Providers
docs.text:
• Simplifies integration by hiding the complexity of:
  • Secure communication
  • Device management
  • Data handling
  • Ensures smooth interoperability across different IoT verticals through standardized APIs.

docs.title: Quick Summary
docs.text: The C-DOT CCSP is a robust, standards-based platform designed to empower IoT/M2M applications across multiple verticals, ensuring secure, scalable, and efficient deployment.

docs.title: Vendor Configuration and Onboarding Process for IR-NIYANTRAC
Vendor Configuration
docs.text: The vendor on receipt of Letter of Acceptance (LoA) from the respective railways shall have to contact the SSE (Station Engineer) for its vendor configuration. The vendor shall provide all the details as specified in Clause 18 of the published IR-NIYANTRAC Message Format document.

docs.title: SSE Responsibilities
docs.text:
The SSE will be configuring the vendor details on the IR-NIYANTRAC portal. Additionally, the SSE shall configure the Intelligent Field Devices (IFDs) and their associated assets for the vendor.

Once the IFDs and their assets are configured, the SSE shall email the configuration file for the configured IFD to its vendor.

docs.title: Onboarding Devices
docs.text: The vendors have to proceed with onboarding of their devices on the production setup (ccsp.railsaver.gov.in), after they have completed their testing of the firmware for the IFD on the test infrastructure (https://coi.cdot.in).

docs.title: C-DOT Test Infrastructure
docs.text:
C-DOT provides a test infrastructure for testing IR-NIYANTRAC messages under its COI initiative (https://coi.cdot.in).

For enabling testing on the C-DOT infrastructure, C-DOT requires an email from the CRIS IR-NIYANTRAC team. This email includes: - Vendor details. - Confirmation that the vendor is valid and holds an LoA for the specified area.

Once the email is received from CRIS by C-DOT: 1. The vendor will be configured on the COI infrastructure. 2. CRIS will configure the IFD details on the COI for the vendor. 3. The CRIS team will then email the IFD configuration details to the vendor for their testing.

docs.title: Post-Testing Steps
docs.text:
After receiving the configuration details, at a high level, the following steps shall be performed (for detailed flow and understanding, refer to the IR-NIYANTRAC Message Format document):

  1. The vendor shall then generate a certificate for the IFD as specified in Clause 16 of the IR-NIYANTRAC Message Format document.
  2. The vendor’s IFD shall then create the containers and associated subscriptions as per Clause 8 of the IR-NIYANTRAC Message Format document.
  3. Once the containers and subscriptions data have been created successfully, the vendor’s IFD can then send field data for various use cases, such as lifts, water pumps, etc., from the IFD as outlined in Clause 10.

docs.title: OneM2M - App-ID Registration
docs.text: The vendor will register the App-ID in the OneM2M App-ID Registry as Ra1.<vendor_domain>.irn. For more details, visit the OneM2M App-ID Registry.

docs.title: App-ID Registration Process
docs.text:
It may take 2 business days for the registration of App-Id in oneM2M, kindly note the App-Id at the time of registration. This App-Id can be mailed as per the clause 18.2 of the Communication Message Format (as per oneM2M standard) Document

Below is a picture that shows how the OneM2M App-ID Registry looks like

docs.title: IR-NIYANTRAC Messages
docs.text: IR-NIYANTRAC Messages outlines the framework for message communication between IoT devices. It provides structured guidance on communication protocols and message formats adhering to the oneM2M standard, ensuring the standardized communication in IoT ecosystems.

docs.title: Download the Latest Version:
docs.text: Download Communication Message Format (as per oneM2M standard)

docs.title: Connect Time/Sync Ack
docs.text:
## Payload with Data Types: (Created by CRIS, received as notification by device)

{
    "op": 1,
    "to": "<container-ResourceId>",
    "fr": "<CRIS-AE-ID>",
    "rqi": "<unique-Request-Identifier>",
    "ty": 4,
    "pc": {
        "m2m:cin": {
            "lbl": ["TMSYNCNT"],
            "cnf": "irn:tsynA",
            "con": {
                "devID": <String value>,
                "vndID": <String value>,
                "msgTy": <String value>,
                "ctlTy": <String value>,
                "serTm": <String value>
            }
        }
    },
    "rvi": "3"
}

## Payload with Sample Values:

{
    "op": 1,
    "to": "<container-ResourceId>",
    "fr": "<CRIS-AE-ID>",
    "rqi": "<unique-Request-Identifier>",
    "ty": 4,
    "pc": {
        "m2m:cin": {
            "lbl": ["TMSYNCNT"],
            "cnf": "irn:tsynA",
            "con": {
                "devID": "0362500001",
                "vndID": "11",
                "msgTy": "04",
                "ctlTy": "03",
                "serTm": "261020220751354"
            }
        }
    },
    "rvi": "3"
}
Field Descriptions:
  • op (Operation): 1 signifies a create operation.
  • to (To): The target resource, represented by <container-ResourceId>.
  • fr (From): The originator of the request, represented by <CRIS-AE-ID>.
  • rqi (Request Identifier): A unique request identifier.
  • ty (Resource Type): 4 represents a content instance resource.
  • pc (Primitive Content): Contains the actual request data.
    • m2m:cin: Represents the <contentInstance> object containing:
      • lbl: The labels attached to the <contentInstance> resource in the request.
      • cnf: It represents the content info attribute of the <contentInstance> resource.
      • con: The content of the <contentInstance> resource.
  • rvi (Release Version Indicator): Specifies the version of the oneM2M release being used in the request.

docs.title: Alert Container Subscription
docs.text:
This payload creates a subscription resource for the alert container. It is used to enable event notifications based on certain conditions, such as thresholds or specific data changes. 

## Payload with Sample Values:

{
    "op": 1,
    "to": "<container-ResourceId>",
    "fr": "<DEVICE-AE-ID>",
    "rqi": "<unique-Request-Identifier>",
    "ty": 23,
    "pc": {
        "m2m:sub": {
            "rn": "ALTSUB",
            "enc": {
                "net": [3],
                "chty": [4]
            },
            "eeno": true,
            "nu": [
                "<registrarUrl>/oneM2M/req/irn/alt/json"
            ],
            "nct": 1
        }
    },
    "rvi": "3"
}
Field Descriptions:
  • op (Operation): 1 signifies a create operation for the subscription.
  • to: The target resource for the subscription, represented by <container-ResourceId>.
  • fr (From): The originator of the request, represented by <DEVICE-AE-ID>.
  • rqi (Request Identifier): A unique request identifier used for tracking the subscription request.
  • ty (Resource Type): 23 indicates the subscription resource type.
  • pc (Payload Content): Contains the details of the subscription, such as:
    • rn: The name of the subscription, here represented as "ALTSUB".
    • enc: Encoding details for the subscription, including:
      • net: A list of notification types, here [3].
      • chty: A list of content types, here [4].
    • eeno: Indicates if event notifications are enabled; set to true.
    • nu: The URL for the notification receiving endpoint, here <registrarUrl>/oneM2M/req/irn/json.
    • nct: The notification condition type, set to 1.
  • rvi: Specifies the release version of the oneM2M protocol being used, here "3".

docs.title: Alert Buffer Container Subscription
docs.text:
This payload creates a subscription resource for the alert buffer container. It is used to enable event notifications based on specific conditions or resource changes. 

## Payload with Sample Values:

{
    "op": 1,
    "to": "<container-ResourceId>",
    "fr": "<DEVICE-AE-ID>",
    "rqi": "<unique-Request-Identifier>",
    "ty": 23,
    "pc": {
        "m2m:sub": {
            "rn": "ALTBUFSUB",
            "enc": {
                "net": [3],
                "chty": [4]
            },
            "eeno": true,
            "nu": [
                "<registrarUrl>/oneM2M/req/irnbuf/alt/json"
            ],
            "nct": 1
        }
    },
    "rvi": "3"
}
Field Descriptions:
  • op (Operation): 1 signifies a create operation for the subscription.
  • to: The target resource for the subscription, represented by <container-ResourceId>.
  • fr (From): The originator of the request, represented by <DEVICE-AE-ID>.
  • rqi (Request Identifier): A unique request identifier for tracking the subscription request.
  • ty (Resource Type): 23 indicates a subscription resource.
  • pc (Payload Content): Contains the subscription details:
    • rn (Resource Name): The name of the subscription resource, e.g., ALTBUFSUB.
    • enc (Event Notification Criteria): Contains:
      • net (Notification Event Types): Notification event types. Here, 3 represents updates.
      • chty (Child Resource Types): Child resource types to monitor. Here, 4 represents content instances.
    • eeno (Event Notification Optimization): Whether event notification optimization is enabled (true/false).
    • nu (Notification URI): The list of URIs for receiving notifications, e.g., <registrarUrl>/oneM2M/req/irnbuf/alt/json.
    • nct (Notification Content Type): Indicates the type of content to include in the notification. Here, 1 represents resource representation.
  • rvi (Release Version Indicator): Specifies the oneM2M protocol version used, here "3".

docs.title: Field Descriptions:
docs.text:
• op (Operation): 1 signifies a create operation.
  • to (To): The target resource, represented by <container-ResourceId>.
  • fr (From): The originator of the request, represented by <DEVICE-AE-ID>.
  • rqi (Request Identifier): A unique request identifier.
  • ty (Resource Type): 4 represents a content instance resource.
  • msgTy (Message Type): Message Type (String value).
  • ot (Originating Timestamp): The current Timestamp of the device when the request is made.
  • pc (Primitive Content): Contains the actual request data.
  • m2m:cin: Represents the <contentInstance> object containing:
    • lbl: The labels attached to the <contentInstance> resource in the request.
    • cnf: Represents the content info attribute of the <contentInstance> resource.
    • con: The content of the <contentInstance> resource.
  • rvi (Release Version Indicator): Specifies the version of the oneM2M release being used in the request.
